Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Research Experiences in Changing Coastal Environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium (LUMCON), located in Cocodrie, LA. The program will support six students per year during a ten week summer research program. Students will conduct independent research projects and participate in a series of seminars in marine sciences and career workshops. Student research projects at LUMCON will focus on the coastal zone environment that is being impacted by climate change and more direct human impacts, including fisheries, transportation, and industry. Coastal Louisiana may serve as an ideal model system to study these impacts because rates of environmental change here are substantially greater than many other coastal systems in the US and around the world. The goal of the proposed LUMCON REU site is to provide stimulating, challenging, and lasting research experiences for a highly qualified, diverse cohort of 6 undergraduate student participants from throughout the United States. In meeting this goal, specific objectives of the LUMCON REU program are to 1) expose students to a variety of research settings and
disciplines of coastal and marine science, 2) facilitate the design, implementation and completion of
individual, independent research projects, 3) train students in basic research skills in oral and written
scientific presentation skills, 4) expose participants to the diversity of career paths that exist in science as well as a diverse ensemble of role models, 5) teach participants about the linkages between scientific research and ecosystem management, and 6) develop a cohort of future scientists through a common
research experience and opportunities for both formal and informal exchange and communication between students and between students and mentors. NSF funding provides for student stipends, travel, room and board in the LUMCON dormitory, student research expenses and administrative costs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided funding for creating a new site in the National Science Foundation’s “Research Experiences for Undergraduates” (REU) program at the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium (LUMCON), located in Cocodrie, LA. LUMCON’s “Interdisciplinary Research Experiences in Changing Coastal Environments” REU program was funded to support six students per year during a ten week summer research program over three summers. Throughout each summer, undergraduate college students in the program acquire “hands on” research experience conducting independent research projects, participate in career and skill-building workshops, go on field trips and are exposed to a diversity of research projects through both a formal seminar series and informal opportunities. Student research projects focus on the coastal zone environment that is being impacted by climate change and more direct human impacts, including fisheries, transportation, and industry. Areas of research have included biogeochemistry, benthic ecology, coastal geology, hypoxia, ecosystem ecology, fisheries and aquaculture, wetland science and Gulf Oil Spill impacts. Coastal Louisiana serves as an ideal model system to study these impacts because rates of environmental change here are substantially greater than many other coastal systems in the US and around the world.

The goal of the LUMCON REU site is to provide stimulating, challenging, and lasting research experiences for a highly qualified, diverse cohort of undergraduate student participants from throughout the United States. In meeting this goal, specific objectives of the LUMCON REU program are to 1) expose students to a variety of research settings and disciplines of coastal and marine science, 2) facilitate the design, implementation and completion of individual, independent research projects, 3) train students in basic research skills in oral and written scientific presentation skills, 4) expose participants to the diversity of career paths that exist in science as well as a diverse ensemble of role models, 5) teach participants about the linkages between scientific research and ecosystem management, and 6) develop a cohort of future scientists through a common research experience and opportunities for both formal and informal exchange and communication between students and between students and mentors.

A secondary goal of LUMCON’s NSF REU Site grant is to provide a framework to enhance the overall research opportunities for undergraduate students at LUMCON's DeFelice Marine Center. This REU site grant provided direct funding support for 18 REU interns over three years.  Through leveraging of support from other research grants and external funding sources, we were able to support a total of 29 undergraduates to participate REU program activities over 4 years. LUMCON REU Site has been successful in providing research opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduate students with the 2011-2014 cohorts including 59% women, 52% rising seniors, 25% underrepresented groups, 25% first generation college students, 17% non-traditional students, and 45% from non-PhD granting institutions.
